factoid: The Rostóvs went nowhere the day after the opera.
Nobody came to see the Rostóvs that day.
Márya Dmítrievna talked to the count about something.
The count and Márya Dmítrievna concealed that something from Natásha.
Natásha guessed that Márya Dmítrievna and the count were talking about the old prince.
Natásha guessed that Márya Dmítrievna and the count were planning something.
This disquieted Natásha.
This offended Natásha.
Natásha was expecting Prince Andrew any moment.
Natásha sent a manservant to the Vozdvízhenka twice that day.
The manservant was sent to ascertain whether Prince Andrew had come.
Prince Andrew had not arrived.
Natásha suffered more now than during her first days in Moscow.
Natásha's impatience and pining for Prince Andrew were now added to an unpleasant recollection of her interview with Princess Mary and the old prince.
Natásha had a fear and anxiety of which she did not understand the cause.
Natásha continually fancied that Prince Andrew would never come.
Natásha continually fancied that something would happen to Natásha before Prince Andrew came.
Natásha could no longer think of Prince Andrew by herself calmly and continuously as she had done before.
As Natásha began to think of Prince Andrew, recollection of the old prince mingled with Natásha's thoughts.
As Natásha began to think of Prince Andrew, recollection of Princess Mary mingled with Natásha's thoughts.
As Natásha began to think of Prince Andrew, recollection of the theater mingled with Natásha's thoughts.
As Natásha began to think of Prince Andrew, recollection of Kurágin mingled with Natásha's thoughts.
Natásha questioned whether she was not guilty.
Natásha questioned whether she had not already broken faith with Prince Andrew.

Natásha recalled to the minutest detail every word, every gesture, and every shade in the play of expression on the face of the man who had been able to arouse in Natásha such an incomprehensible and terrifying feeling.
Natásha seemed livelier than usual to the family.
Natásha was far less tranquil than before.
Natásha was far less happy than before.
On Sunday morning Márya Dmítrievna invited her visitors to Mass at her parish church.
The parish church is the Church of the Assumption built over the graves of victims of the plague.
Márya Dmítrievna said that Márya Dmítrievna does not like those fashionable churches.
Márya Dmítrievna prided herself on her independence of thought.
Márya Dmítrievna said that God is the same everywhere.
Márya Dmítrievna said that they have an excellent priest who conducts the service decently and with dignity.
Márya Dmítrievna said that the deacon is the same.
Márya Dmítrievna asked what holiness is there in giving concerts in the choir.
Márya Dmítrievna said that she does not like it and that it is just self-indulgence.
Márya Dmítrievna liked Sundays.
Márya Dmítrievna knew how to keep Sundays.
Márya Dmítrievna's whole house was scrubbed and cleaned on Saturdays.
Neither Márya Dmítrievna nor the servants worked on Saturdays.
The servants wore holiday dress on Saturdays.
The servants went to church on Saturdays.
At Márya Dmítrievna's table there were extra dishes at dinner.
The servants had vodka at dinner.
The servants had roast goose at dinner.
The servants had suckling pig at dinner.
The holiday was not noticeable in the house except in Márya Dmítrievna’s broad, stern face.
On that day Márya Dmítrievna’s broad, stern face wore an invariable look of solemn festivity.
After Mass they finished their coffee in the dining room where loose covers had been removed from the furniture.
A servant announced that the carriage was ready.
Márya Dmítrievna rose with a stern air.
Márya Dmítrievna wore her holiday shawl.
Márya Dmítrievna paid calls in her holiday shawl.
Márya Dmítrievna announced that she was going to see Prince Nicholas Bolkónski.
Márya Dmítrievna wanted an explanation with Prince Nicholas Bolkónski about Natásha.
After Márya Dmítrievna had gone, a dressmaker from Madame Suppert-Roguet waited on the Rostóvs.
Natásha was very glad of this diversion.
Natásha shut herself into a room adjoining the drawing room.
Natásha occupied herself trying on the new dresses.
Natásha put on a bodice without sleeves that was only tacked together.
Natásha turned her head to see in the glass how the back fitted.
Natásha heard in the drawing room the animated sounds of her father's voice.
Natásha heard in the drawing room the animated sounds of another woman's voice.
The woman's voice was Hélène.
Natásha had not time to take off the bodice before the door opened.
Countess Bezúkhova, dressed in a purple velvet gown with a high collar, came into the room.
Countess Bezúkhova beamed with good-humored amiable smiles.
Countess Bezúkhova cried to the blushing Natásha, "Oh, my enchantress!"
Countess Bezúkhova said to Count Rostóv that he was charming.
Countess Bezúkhova said that this is really beyond anything.
Countess Bezúkhova addressed Count Rostóv as my dear count.
Countess Bezúkhova asked how Count Rostóv could live in Moscow and go nowhere.
Countess Bezúkhova said she will not let Count Rostóv off.
Countess Bezúkhova said that Mademoiselle George will recite at her house tonight.
Countess Bezúkhova said there will be some people.
Countess Bezúkhova said that if Count Rostóv does not bring his lovely girls who are prettier than Mademoiselle George, she will not know him.
Countess Bezúkhova said that her husband is away in Tver or she will send him to fetch Count Rostóv.
Countess Bezúkhova said that Count Rostóv must come.
Countess Bezúkhova said that Count Rostóv must come between eight and nine.
